title-group.article-title: A Randomized Controlled Trial of the Implementation of BREASTChoice, a Multilevel Breast Reconstruction Decision Support Tool With Personalized Risk Prediction

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Surgery, Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, MO, USA
2Department of Medicine, Washington University School of Medicine, Saint Louis, MO, USA
3Division of Health Services Management and Policy, College of Public Health, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH
5Living Beyond Breast Cancer, Bala Cynwyd, PA, USA
7Renaissance Plastic Surgery, St. Peters, MO, USA
8The Breakfast Club, Inc., St. Louis, MO, USA
9Department of Surgery, University of North Carolina School of Medicine, Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center, Chapel Hill, NC, USA

fn.p: Author Contributions: Mary C. Politi, PhD, co-Principal investigator of the study, supervised data collection at Site A, meaningfully engaged in data analysis decisions, wrote the initial draft of the paper, revised it with the team, and approved the final version. Terence M. Myckatyn, MD, co-investigator of the study, facilitated data collection, reviewed data analysis for clinical interpretation of results, revised the paper draft with critical feedback, and approved the final version. Krista Cooksey, BA, participated in data collection, data analysis, data extraction from the EHR, drafted sections of the methods and results of the paper, revised it with the team, and approved the final version. Margaret A. Olsen, PhD, MPH, led the development of the risk prediction model, oversaw the EHR integration of the risk prediction, drafted sections of the risk prediction in the manuscript, revised the manuscript with critical feedback, and approved the final version. Rachel M. Smith, PhD, MPH, led the statistical analysis of results, revised the results section of the paper, and approved the final version. Randi Foraker, PhD, MA, led the EHR integration and informatics process, reviewed data analysis, revised the manuscript with critical feedback, and approved the final version. Katelyn Parrish, MPH and Crystal Phommasathit, MPH participated in data collection, data extraction from the EHR, revised the manuscript, and approved the final version. Guy Brock, PhD supervised the data analysis, led the analysis of the risk prediction model for the control group participants at Site B, revised the results section of the paper, and approved the final version. Sarah Janse, PhD designed the randomization of the study, set up the data collection procedures, contributed to the statistical analysis plan, revised the results section of the paper and approved the final version. Janine Guglielmino, MA, Anne Peled, MD, MPH, Paul B. Mills, MD and Sherrill Jackson, CPNP participated in the advisory board based on patient and clinician perspectives, contributed to the design, conduct, and data results interpretation, provided critical feedback and approved the final version. Clara N. Lee, MD, MPP, co-Principal investigator of the study, supervised data collection at Site B, meaningfully engaged in data analysis decisions, co-wrote drafts of the paper, revised it with the team, and approved the final version.

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Mary C. Politi, PhD., Division of Public Health Sciences, Department of Surgery, Washington University School of Medicine, 660 S Euclid Ave, MSC 8100-94-02, St. Louis, MO 63110, Fax 314-747-1020; mpoliti@wustl.edu

related-article.article-title: A Randomized Controlled Trial of the Implementation of BREASTChoice, a Multilevel Breast Reconstruction Decision Support Tool With Personalized Risk Prediction: Erratum.

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To implement the BREASTChoice decision tool into the electronic health record and evaluate its effectiveness.

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: BREASTChoice, is a multilevel decision tool that: 1) educates patients about breast reconstruction; 2) estimates personalized risk of complications; 3) clarifies patient preferences; and 4) informs clinicians about patients’ risk and preferences.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: A multisite randomized controlled trial enrolled adult women with stage 0-III breast malignancy undergoing mastectomy. Participants were randomized to BREASTChoice or a control website. A survey assessed knowledge, preferences, decisional conflict, shared decision-making, preferred treatment, and usability. We conducted intent-to-treat (ITT), per-protocol (PP) analyses (those randomized to BREASTChoice who accessed the tool), and stratified analyses.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: 23/25 eligible clinicians enrolled. 369/761 (48%) contacted patients enrolled and were randomized. Patients’ average age was 51 years; 15% were older than 65. BREASTChoice participants had higher knowledge than control participants (ITT: mean 70.6 vs. 67.4, p=0.08; PP: mean 71.4 vs. 67.4, p=0.03), especially when stratified by site (ITT: p=0.04, PP: p=0.01), age (ITT: p=0.04, PP: p=0.02), and race (ITT: p=0.04, PP: p=0.01). BREASTChoice did not improve decisional conflict, match between preferences and treatment, or shared decision-making. In PP analyses, fewer high-risk patients using BREASTChoice chose reconstruction. BREASTChoice had high usability.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: BREASTChoice is a novel decision tool incorporating risk prediction, patient education, and clinician engagement. Patients using BREASTChoice had higher knowledge; older adults and those from racially minoritized backgrounds especially benefitted. There was no impact on other decision outcomes. Future studies should overcome implementation barriers and specifically examine decision outcomes among high-risk patients.

abstract.title: Mini Abstract:
abstract.p: BREASTChoice is the first breast reconstruction decision tool, to our knowledge, that incorporates personalized risk prediction, evidence-based patient education, and clinician decision support. This paper reports on a multisite randomized controlled trial evaluating the implementation of the BREASTChoice tool into the electronic health record, examining its impact on decision quality, surgical choice, and shared decision-making.
